Very Attractive.

The Johns Hopkins Dramatic
Club will put on its first production of the year Wednesday night
in its studio on the top floor ot
the Barn. Only two plays will be
presented, "A Death in Fever
Flat," a one-act tragedy by Cronyn, and "A Roadhouse in Arden," by Philip Moeller.
The plays are coming along
very well in rehearsal and Mariano Badillo promises some unusual scenic effect particularly in
the Moeller burlesque, "A Roadhouse in Arden." He has also designed costumes which very effectively suggest the extraordinary atmosphere of the piece. The
tragedy,"A Death in Fever Flat"
presents a •real problem. It is a
tense, strident affair presenting
technical difficulties demanding
the utmost skill from the actors.
Slatkin as "Miss Immortality,"
in "A Roadhouse in Arden," and
White as "Padie" in "A Death in
Fever Flat," bid fair to live up to
the greatest tradition of the club.
Both make very attractive ladies,
but "Don" Kirkley and "Cleopatra FIamlet" promises to be the
most seductive thing this side of
the Mohammedan heaven.
Buckheister and Hess have
heavy acting parts in the tragedy
and Hunter has to support most
of the comedy work in the burlesque.
Henry West and Eli Frank, Jr.,
coached the plays.
The curtain will slide at 815.

- The Sophomore and Freshmen
teams are going through hard
Practices daily in preparation for
the interclass game on Saturday.
The Sophomores have been holding practice for over a week and
their team is beginning to round
into form. The difficulty which
the Sophomores must face is the
same difficulty which has resulted so often heretofore in the defeat of a seemingly stronger team
by a materially weaker one on paper; the absence of teamwork.
Strenuous practices, however,
are erasing the rough spots and
the second year team- is rapidly
rounding into condition. Many of
the men who were out for the
Varsity are trying.for_ the team
and these meh are a big asset in
teaching some of their less experienced classmates some of the
fine points of the game.
The Freshmen team has been
Practicing steadily and with each
Practice more improvement can
be noticed. The Freshmen were
handicapped this year by lack of
games and were defeated in their
only start by Severn School.
They have shown a complete reversal of form since then, however, in several scrimmages with
local prep schools and the first
Year team now seems to be at the

A. A. BOARD HOLDS MEETING

At the last meeting of the A. A.
Board, called to order by President Knecht at 12.20 in the athletic office of the barn on Monday, November 21, it was decided
to take definite action regarding
the awarding of gold footballs to
those Hopkins football men who
helped to win the state championship. It has always been the
custom in the past to award some
such emblem to the members of
state championship teams and the
:ustom will be continued this year.
It has not yet been determined
how the emblem will be obtained.
The footballs will either be donated by some philanthropically
inclined graduate or will be purchased with funds collected by
public subscription of the student
body. The men who will receive
the emblems will be those who
participated in the St. John's
game and also any who are awarded the "H" but still did not play
against St. John's.

Very Attractive.

The Johns Hopkins Dramatic
Club will put on its first production of the year Wednesday night
in its studio on the top floor ot
the Barn. Only two plays will be
presented, "A Death in Fever
Flat," a one-act tragedy by Cronyn, and "A Roadhouse in Arden," by Philip Moeller.
The plays are coming along
very well in rehearsal and Mariano Badillo promises some unusual scenic effect particularly in
the Moeller burlesque, "A Roadhouse in Arden." He has also designed costumes which very effectively suggest the extraordinary atmosphere of the piece. The
tragedy,"A Death in Fever Flat"
presents a •real problem. It is a
tense, strident affair presenting
technical difficulties demanding
the utmost skill from the actors.
Slatkin as "Miss Immortality,"
in "A Roadhouse in Arden," and
White as "Padie" in "A Death in
Fever Flat," bid fair to live up to
the greatest tradition of the club.
Both make very attractive ladies,
but "Don" Kirkley and "Cleopatra FIamlet" promises to be the
most seductive thing this side of
the Mohammedan heaven.
Buckheister and Hess have
heavy acting parts in the tragedy
and Hunter has to support most
of the comedy work in the burlesque.
Henry West and Eli Frank, Jr.,
coached the plays.
The curtain will slide at 815.

- The Sophomore and Freshmen
teams are going through hard
Practices daily in preparation for
the interclass game on Saturday.
The Sophomores have been holding practice for over a week and
their team is beginning to round
into form. The difficulty which
the Sophomores must face is the
same difficulty which has resulted so often heretofore in the defeat of a seemingly stronger team
by a materially weaker one on paper; the absence of teamwork.
Strenuous practices, however,
are erasing the rough spots and
the second year team- is rapidly
rounding into condition. Many of
the men who were out for the
Varsity are trying.for_ the team
and these meh are a big asset in
teaching some of their less experienced classmates some of the
fine points of the game.
The Freshmen team has been
Practicing steadily and with each
Practice more improvement can
be noticed. The Freshmen were
handicapped this year by lack of
games and were defeated in their
only start by Severn School.
They have shown a complete reversal of form since then, however, in several scrimmages with
local prep schools and the first
Year team now seems to be at the

A. A. BOARD HOLDS MEETING

At the last meeting of the A. A.
Board, called to order by President Knecht at 12.20 in the athletic office of the barn on Monday, November 21, it was decided
to take definite action regarding
the awarding of gold footballs to
those Hopkins football men who
helped to win the state championship. It has always been the
custom in the past to award some
such emblem to the members of
state championship teams and the
:ustom will be continued this year.
It has not yet been determined
how the emblem will be obtained.
The footballs will either be donated by some philanthropically
inclined graduate or will be purchased with funds collected by
public subscription of the student
body. The men who will receive
the emblems will be those who
participated in the St. John's
game and also any who are awarded the "H" but still did not play
against St. John's.
